awd_titl_txt: ADVANCE Institutional Transformation at the University of New Mexico
awd_abstract_narration:
The ADVANCE program is designed to foster gender equity through a focus on the identification and elimination of organizational barriers that impede the full participation and advancement of women faculty in academic institutions.  Organizational barriers that inhibit equity may exist in areas such as policy, practice, culture, and organizational climate.  The ADVANCE Institutional Transformation (ADVANCE-IT) track supports the development of innovative organizational change strategies within an institution of higher education to enhance gender equity in the science, technology, engineering, and math (STEM) disciplines.

The University of New Mexico's (UNM) ADVANCE-IT project will create the Institute for Diversity and Equity Across STEM (IDEAS) to serve as the organizational catalyst of institutional transformation, promoting gender equity in the recruitment, retention and advancement of STEM faculty.  UNM is in a majority-minority state and is a Carnegie Very High Research Activity University and a Hispanic-Serving Institution with a diverse student body.  The project will implement strategies to engage STEM leaders, including senior faculty, as partners; create mentoring and networking programs; and improve the transparency of policies and processes that impact faculty.

IDEAS will implement a "managerial engagement model" developed by sociologists Dobbin and Kalev which proposes that engaging managers in programs to promote diversity, including connections with underrepresented groups, enhances their motivation and changes attitudes.  IDEAS will show how this managerial engagement model, an evidence-based approach to promote diversity in organizational leadership, can be applied to universities.  In addition, IDEAS will incorporate an intersectional perspective to address the distinct situations of minority women in STEM.  IDEAS will generate evidence to inform comparative analyses of factors influencing the advancement of women and minorities across different types of organizations as well as of the strategies most appropriate to different subgroups of women. The goals of the project include the creation of a more inclusive, egalitarian, and supportive institutional climate and improving satisfaction with, and perceptions of fairness of, the tenure and promotion process at UNM.

por.por_cntn:
The ADVANCE at UNM Institutional Transformation project has aimed to create sustainable changes that foster a more equitable and inclusive climate, allowing faculty with a broad range of backgrounds and experiences to thrive and contribute to the success of our diverse student body. We have successfully contributed to new policies and processes; increased support and training for faculty hiring, promotion & tenure; and established collaborations across the campus. As a result of our efforts, ADVANCE at UNM has fulfilled the goal of securing Academic Affairs funding as part of the infrastructure necessary to support faculty and academic leaders. Some of the areas in which ADVANCE at UNM has had a substantive impact include:

  • Creating a more inclusive and supportive institutional climate
  • Increasing resources and support for faculty academic success
  • Supporting the diverse needs of faculty during the pandemic and in the aftermath
  • Communicating faculty opportunities, successes, and concerns within UNM and beyond

Creating a More Inclusive and Supportive Institutional Climate

Improving institutional climate for all faculty requires an understanding of faculty experiences and perspectives, transparent policies and processes, and leaders who are knowledgeable about these policies and processes. The ADVANCE biennial main campus faculty climate surveys have informed discussions with leaders, improved policy implementation, and led to new opportunities and resources. Our Parental Leave Report, partially based on survey results, led to improved consistency in communication about this important policy. Academic leaders have noticeably increased the attention given to faculty issues. All main campus Schools and Colleges now have an Associate Dean for Faculty (ADF), whereas most did not when ADVANCE was funded in 2016. The ADFs meet monthly with the Senior Vice Provost (SVP) and ADVANCE Director, and main campus department chairs and directors now meet 3-4 times per semester with topics coordinated by the Associate Provost for Faculty (APFac), the SVP and ADVANCE. Guidelines for the promotion & tenure (P&T) process are accessible through a header on the Provost’s home page rather than buried on the home page of an office within Academic Affairs. ADVANCE offers confidential meetings to faculty, chairs, and directors who want support in understanding and implementation of UNM policies and processes. We have contributed to increased transparency and equitable implementation of policies and processes relevant to faculty hiring, retention, and advancement.

Increasing resources and support for faculty academic success

ADVANCE has worked with the APFac to coordinate faculty development opportunities and resources on campus through a Faculty Development Council. This group has worked to improve New Faculty Orientation, encourage participation in faculty development opportunities, and provide extra faculty support during the pandemic. ADVANCE partners with Academic Affairs to offer workshops to support faculty in the P&T process from their first semester as assistant professor through promotion to professor. Each year, we offer a workshop on annual and milestone evaluations for new faculty and a workshop on preparing the research, teaching, and service statements required for P&T dossiers. Notably, we provide support for associate professors, including a new associate professor orientation and a workshop on planning for promotion to professor. We offer a range of other workshops, including six workshops per year in collaboration with the Faculty Research Development Office, supporting faculty in the development of research, scholarship and creative works. The ADVANCE Best Practices in Faculty Search workshops, offered in collaboration with Academic affairs and required of academic leaders and search committee chairs, have also contributed to a decrease in administrative obstacles that were frustrating faculty hiring committees.

Supporting the diverse needs of faculty during the pandemic and in the aftermath

UNM operated remotely for over 15 months. During this time, ADVANCE pivoted to helping faculty understand the rapidly changing guidance and expectations while effectively relaying faculty concerns and ideas to academic leaders. We developed a webpage to provide faculty with a one-stop location to track UNM changes, COVID information, support resources, and opportunities. The latest version of this webpage remains one of our most frequently visited. Our special pandemic impact surveys and reports contributed to the development of the opt-out tenure extension, a new template for contacting external reviewers for P&T evaluation, regular meetings on faculty issues for department chairs, and on-going programs from the Office of the Vice President for Research to support faculty in overcoming research delays. To address the needs of new faculty, we've developed webpages providing overviews of UNM faculty resources and that guide faculty in identifying support resources for students.

Communicating faculty opportunities and successes within UNM and beyond

We developed a visible presence on campus through our website, YouTube channel, Facebook page, social media posts, and weekly emails. We've used short news stories and videos to highlight faculty accomplishments beyond the UNM community, including through on-going collaboration with University Communications & Marketing. Promoting faculty accomplishments contributes to their international reputations and advancement.
